info.name: OAuth Demos (JWT)
info.description:
This collection is a "pure" OAuth set of calls that has no UI wrapped around the request \ response that mimic OAuth Playground for PingFed.

Calls that require a Web Browser (AuthZ Code or Implicit) are marked "(Browser)" these calls should be pasted into a Web Browser to be completed - this is to bypass any UI that Postman uses with the Authorization --> OAuth 2.0 mechanism.

Update: 11/25/18
Added the following flows:
    SAML Bearer
    JWT Bearer
    Device Flow (PF 9.2+)
Added examples using x-www-form-urlencoded body for call parameters
Organized calls a little better
Indicated PF versions for more recent support

item.name: OAuth Token Requests
User Authentication
OAuth Demo - AuthZ - Get AuthZ Code (Browser)

request.description:
Demonstrates a regular Authorization Code request.

The Code will be sent to the redirect_uri value. The code then needs to be posted to the AS to receive an access_token.

item.name: OAuth Demo - AuthZ - Swap Code for Token(s)

request.description: Demonstrates the call to swap an AuthZ Code for an access_token

item.name: AuthZ Code with PKCE (PF 8.4+)
OAuth Demo - AuthZ - Get Code with PKCE (Browser)

request.description:
Demonstrates a regular Authorization Code request.

The Code will be sent to the redirect_uri value. The code then needs to be posted to the AS to receive an access_token.

This adds a ?code_challenge= string to the Code request.

item.name: OAuth Demo - AuthZ - Swap Code for Token(s) with PKCE

request.description:
Demonstrates the call to swap an AuthZ Code for an access_token when the call was made with PKCE.

The ?code_challenge= value from the previous call needs to be added as the ?code_verifier= parameter

item.description: These calls conform to RFC 7636 (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636) to add additional security into the acquisition of the Authorization Code

item.name: SAML Bearer

body.raw:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
    <soap:Header>
        <wsa:Action xmlns:wsa="http://www.w3.org/2005/08/addressing" xmlns:wsu="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-utility-1.0.xsd" wsu:Id="iJFJKoU2cJbfDgjZTwrmZKpS8nKM">http://docs.oasis-open.org/ws-sx/ws-trust/200512/RST/Issue</wsa:Action>
        <wsse:Security xmlns:wsse="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-secext-1.0.xsd" soap:mustUnderstand="1">
            <wsse:UsernameToken xmlns:wsu="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-utility-1.0.xsd" wsu:Id="ijhaEN438vD_gRUQC06Apb8B43nE">
                <wsse:Username>joe</wsse:Username>
                <wsse:Password Type="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-username-token-profile-1.0#PasswordText">2Federate</wsse:Password>
            </wsse:UsernameToken>
        </wsse:Security>
    </soap:Header>
    <soap:Body xmlns:wsu="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-utility-1.0.xsd" wsu:Id="iGPI7F3OqQHNY_nNdIi6mxp16eqE">
        <wst:RequestSecurityToken xmlns:wst="http://docs.oasis-open.org/ws-sx/ws-trust/200512/">
            <wst:TokenType>urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:saml2-bearer</wst:TokenType>
            <wst:RequestType>http://docs.oasis-open.org/ws-sx/ws-trust/200512/Issue</wst:RequestType>
            <wsp:AppliesTo xmlns:wsp="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/09/policy">
                <wsa:EndpointReference xmlns:wsa="http://www.w3.org/2005/08/addressing">
                    <wsa:Address>https://{{pingfed}}</wsa:Address>
                </wsa:EndpointReference>
            </wsp:AppliesTo>
            <wst:Claims/>
            <wst:OnBehalfOf>
                <wsse:SecurityTokenReference xmlns:wsse="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-secext-1.0.xsd">
                    <wsse:Reference URI="#ijhaEN438vD_gRUQC06Apb8B43nE" ValueType="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-username-token-profile-1.0#UsernameToken"/>
                </wsse:SecurityTokenReference>
            </wst:OnBehalfOf>
        </wst:RequestSecurityToken>
    </soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>

item.name: Swap SAML Assertion for Access Token

item.description:
Swap a SAML Assertion for an Access Token

This flow uses a WSTrustSTS call to swap a Username / Password credential for the SAML Assertion

item.name: JWT Bearer

body.raw:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
    <soap:Header>
        <wsa:Action xmlns:wsa="http://www.w3.org/2005/08/addressing" xmlns:wsu="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-utility-1.0.xsd" wsu:Id="iJFJKoU2cJbfDgjZTwrmZKpS8nKM">http://docs.oasis-open.org/ws-sx/ws-trust/200512/RST/Issue</wsa:Action>
        <wsse:Security xmlns:wsse="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-secext-1.0.xsd" soap:mustUnderstand="1">
            <wsse:UsernameToken xmlns:wsu="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-utility-1.0.xsd" wsu:Id="ijhaEN438vD_gRUQC06Apb8B43nE">
                <wsse:Username>joe</wsse:Username>
                <wsse:Password Type="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-username-token-profile-1.0#PasswordText">2Federate</wsse:Password>
            </wsse:UsernameToken>
        </wsse:Security>
    </soap:Header>
    <soap:Body xmlns:wsu="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-utility-1.0.xsd" wsu:Id="iGPI7F3OqQHNY_nNdIi6mxp16eqE">
        <wst:RequestSecurityToken xmlns:wst="http://docs.oasis-open.org/ws-sx/ws-trust/200512/">
            <wst:TokenType>urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer</wst:TokenType>
            <wst:RequestType>http://docs.oasis-open.org/ws-sx/ws-trust/200512/Issue</wst:RequestType>
            <wsp:AppliesTo xmlns:wsp="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/09/policy">
                <wsa:EndpointReference xmlns:wsa="http://www.w3.org/2005/08/addressing">
                    <wsa:Address>https://{{pingfed}}</wsa:Address>
                </wsa:EndpointReference>
            </wsp:AppliesTo>
            <wst:Claims/>
            <wst:OnBehalfOf>
                <wsse:SecurityTokenReference xmlns:wsse="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-secext-1.0.xsd">
                    <wsse:Reference URI="#ijhaEN438vD_gRUQC06Apb8B43nE" ValueType="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-username-token-profile-1.0#UsernameToken"/>
                </wsse:SecurityTokenReference>
            </wst:OnBehalfOf>
        </wst:RequestSecurityToken>
    </soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>

item.description:
Swap a JWT for an Access Token

This flow uses a WSTrustSTS call to swap a Username / Password credential for the JWT

request.description:
Demonstrates a Resource Owner call to swap a user credential for an access_token.

Typically, this call should be avoided due to the risks of collecting and storing credentials in the app.

item.description: These flows involve a User Authentication before an access_token is issued

item.name: Service Authentication
OAuth Demo - Client Credentials (Basic AuthZ Header)
OAuth Demo - Client Credentials (JWT) - Not Working

exec: // Replace characters according to base64url specifications
// Generate current timestamp with moment library
var privateKey="-----BEGIN EC PRIVATE KEY-----MCQCAQEEH0laOSuEdwlQT087zu28YwaccdYYjQDPhQIBy5kkYz8=-----END EC PRIVATE KEY-----"
// Postman CryptoJS doesn't support RSA or ECDSA signing algorithms - either is needed by PingFed for the signed JWTs in this request
// Alternative may be to use an API to handle the signature - https://documenter.getpostman.com/view/4289664/RWaC4D7b

item.description: These flows involve a Service Authentication before an access_token is issued

These calls demonstrate the OAuth 2.0 flows for getting an Access Token.

The results will depend on how PingFed is configured with the Acces Token Mananger and the Access Token Mappings that are linked to the OAuth clients.

OIDC tokens can be minted by adding the OIDC scopes (openid [address | email | phone | profile]) to the Code \ Access Token requests.

item.name: Token Calls
OAuth Demo - Swap Refresh Token for AT

request.description: Used to swap out a refresh_token for an access_token.
Sends AT to the RS Client that's tied to the *same* AT Manager in PF

AT revocation is only directly supported with Internal Reference.

With JWT, set the "Access Grant GUID Claim Name" in the AT Manager - Advanced Options and then revoke the RT

item.description: These calls are used when you've already obtained the access_token

item.name: Dynamic Client Registation (PF 9.0+)
OAuth Demo - Dynamic Client Registration - Get Token

request.description: This call is made to retrieve an access_token that can be used to make a call to the Dynamic Registration Endpoint

body.raw:
{
	"client_name":"My Sample Client",
	"redirect_uris": "https://apps.cpricedomain.net/OAuthDecode",
	"grant_types": ["authorization_code", "password", "implicit"],
	"response_types": "code token id_token",
	"scope": "openid address email phone profile"
}

request.description:
Used to create an OAuth client with the Dynamic Client Registration endpoint.

Requires an AT with the scope "dev:regClient"

item.description: These calls can be used to show PF support for RFC 7591 - OAuth 2.0 Dynamic Client Registration Protocol (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7591)

item.name: OIDC Endpoints

request.description:
Use access_token in the Authorization: Bearer header to present a User to the UserInfo API.

PF OIDC Policy will use the claims in the AT to figure out th rest of the data.

Attributes in the response will be tied to the AT scopes - minimally must be "openid"

item.description: These calls are the endpoints for OIDC when PingFed is configured as an OpenID Connect Provider (Server Configuration --> Server Settings --> Roles & Protocols --> Enable OAuth2 Authorization Role --> OpenID Connect)
